lorebooks.creator: shapeshifty

1.content:
Level 88 is the 89th level of the Backrooms.
Level 88 consists of an extremely large dining restaurant which loops around an enormous aquarium filled with countless sea creatures from the Frontrooms. The entire facility has a radius of 1 kilometer and is filled with round tables which can fit up to 2 guests, and rectangular tables which can fit 4 guests. Inside the aquarium, many abandoned structures reassembling the popular lost city of Atlantis serve as decoration and decoration only, but due to the water's medium turbidity, these structures may be hard to see.
Level 88 has a strong Wi-Fi signal throughout all the dry parts of the level, which can be accessed without a password for a period of 4 hours. The restaurant in fact works: it serves high-quality seafood dishes, which makes it a popular attraction for couples and tourist families in the Backrooms.
The glass wall that separates the restaurant from the aquarium has a particularly strange property: it can be easily broken. However, due to undetermined reasons, the water may not and will never enter nor flood the diner area. This strange property allows for wanderers to enter the aquarium at their own risk, while not harming or putting the lives of those in the restaurant in danger.
While inside the tank, wanderers will be able to breathe underwater just like regular fish. It is not recommended that unprepared wanderers to break nor enter the tank, as potentially harmful sea creatures may cause serious injuries including death. Swimming too far into the center of the tank is also not recommended. The walls will repair themselves after 8 minutes by unknown means.
The glass seems to be unbreakable from the inside of the tank, meaning that if a wanderer ever gets stuck inside the tank they will either have to wait until someone else breaks the glass from the inside or swim towards the top of the level.

Colonies and Outposts:
M.E.G. Base Atlantis:
Population of around 500 M.E.G. personnel.
Secret radio monitoring and communication base.
Top secret shape-shifting device test location.

Entities:
Waiters
Waiters are regular facelings that can be found all around the restaurant. These entities will take orders from guests who are sitting down and bring them food and drinks prepared by the cooks. All waiters are adults, and they all wear tuxedo suits. After all the guests have eaten, a waiter will bring them a paper bill that contains all the items consumed by them. After paying/trading with the waiters, one may safely exit Level 88.
Cooks
Cooks are also facelings, however they can hardly ever be seen, as most of the time they are located at the kitchens, behind the restaurant opaque walls. These entities are responsible for preparing all the foods and drinks ordered by guests. Small holes located at the wall serve as windows where cooks can hand waiters food to be delivered to the tables. If one peeks through these holes, they may see a cook. Kitchen doors can only be accessed by cooks, meaning that wanderers are unable to enter the kitchens.

Entrances:
Going through silver double doors in Level 610 with "Atlantis' Aquarius" written on them.
Entering any restaurant in Level 11 that serves seafood.
Crawling into a lower cabinet in the kitchen in Level Level 406 might take you here.
No-clipping into an aquarium on Level 43.
Noclipping through a fish tank in Level 570 will send one here.

Exits:
Glass doors at the front serve as a direct entrance to Level 11.
Attempting to enter the kitchen through the kitchen doors will instead take you to The Hub.
Swimming towards the top of the tank will take you to Level 7.

2.content:
Level 89 is the 90th level of the Backrooms.
Level 89 is a complex of oddly connected rooms that expand endlessly. The floors are tile, the walls are torn, dark-colored concrete, and the ceilings are aluminum, metal, or conductive material. The rooms resemble shops, including arts and crafts shops, electronic stores, etc. However, regardless of the room type one is in, there will be one thing consistent throughout the rooms: the overabundance of electricity.
The rooms are typically tiny and rarely large. Furniture is what one would expect from a home improvement store, and it's usually constructed of aluminum, metal, iron, or conductive materials. The most frequent furniture item is a shelf, which may be placed anywhere in the area and contains objects and supplies that can be navigation equipment. Each room will feature shelves that appear to be the same size and style; some rooms are arranged in an orderly fashion, while others are positioned randomly, creating a complicated layout. These rooms feature a maze-like arrangement where the shelves will lead to several dead ends and intersections; in rare cases, the shelves may block all of the room entrances, creating a closed room. This makes navigation difficult since one must climb, crawl, or walk sideways to avoid becoming trapped. The shelves are known for being exceedingly heavy and difficult to move.
There is a counter in the corner of every room. The counter shows up in the room's design-appropriate form. This level's products aren't any of the ones we are familiar with from The Frontrooms, and some of them also appear to have uncertain functions. Some products could combine two products that are not included in our reality tools. Some of these products have unexpectedly odd features, while others are worthless since they don't serve any function. The level also ensures all electrical devices, including those that stray individuals bring into the level, will always have power.
The room has a lot of decorative items, especially lighting that embellishes the ceiling, walls, shelves, and counter. Most other decorative items are electrical items, as they offer beautiful aesthetic views. The electrical decorating items will be put through a lot of effort, especially the lights, which shine quite brightly. Some electrical items may overheat, which can harm or ruin their internal components. An electrical excess may occasionally result in an explosion as well. It is well known that these electrical items will be recovered over time if damaged.
Multiple electrical wires that are braided into complicated patterns hang from the ceiling. Any electrical equipment at this level receives its electricity from these wires. The electricity comes from Level 3 as it provides a large quantity of energy to this level, causing the electricity at this level to have a very strong current‚Äî60 volts up to 500 volts‚Äîwhich causes the level to be hazardous to the environment, thus contact with wire should be avoided at all costs.
Electric wires can occasionally be broken, and wires hanging from the ceiling can spill a lot of electricity. Since the majority of furniture and other items are composed of materials with strong electrical conductivity, the high-voltage leakage may also affect those nearby. Contact with these artifacts will result in shock, injury, and possibly death. Due to the extremely high electrical level, it is possible for electrical appliances to overheat, break, and explode. Broken electrical appliances may also result in high-voltage leakage. It is recommended to stay in a room with less electrical equipment and material conductivity.
You will get an electric shock if you touch a high-voltage electrical source. The amount of electricity that passes through your body will determine how harsh the shock will be. You will suffer tingling, muscular spasms, and difficulty breathing after an electric shock. Although you will feel an electric shock at this intensity, your muscles won't contract, so you'll still be able to move. It is recommended to flee if you find yourself in this circumstance. However, after experiencing an electric shock for more than 7 to 10 seconds, muscles will begin to contract, leading to paralysis or involuntary movement, and eventually passing out. The time of pass out will depend on when the electric shock was received; it can be anywhere from 6 hours to 2 weeks, or it can result in death.

Entities:
Shocker Ghouls are the only known entity on this level. Shocker Ghouls are not harmful to wanderers.

Colonies and Outposts:
There are no known colonies or outposts in this level.

Entrances:
The level has only two known entrances; noclipping via Level 3 or Level 88.

Exits:
The room's seemingly inaccessible door will lead to Level 90.
Entering a large workshop and playing any musical instrument will transport you to a workshop section of Level 444 when exiting the door.

3.content:
Level 90, otherwise known as "The Funspace", is an infinite segmentation of small, claustrophobic rooms styled to resemble a child's birthday party. The appearance of each room varies greatly while still containing the same consistent layout. While the flooring, wallpaper, and ceilings vary, each space possesses the same dull yellow tone for its walls and the same red tint for its carpeting. Each room, square in shape, leads to one or more rooms via a small doorway in its wall. These doors, however, may be irregularly placed and appear to be slightly above the ground. The rooms are usually devoid of content but may contain one or more pieces of randomly placed furniture. The walls of each space are decorated with disturbing drawings of characters from popular childhood shows, often portraying them in a distorted or warped style. It is unknown whether these drawings were manually sketched onto the level's walls or if they are part of the level itself. The ceilings of each room are covered with two fluorescent light panels that emit a quiet hum. Many wanderers who have closely listened to ceilings have reported faint whispers from above the level.
Throughout the level, an indeterminable source endlessly plays a short piano song that is extremely detuned, amplifying the eeriness of the level. Additionally, this song has abnormally strong echoes as it resonates through the entirety of the level for long periods. This song appears to be a mental hazard for wanderers, as those who are exposed to this tune will undergo feelings of sadness or neglect as if they had been ignored for their entire lives. This often leads to insecurity and anxiety, thereby making the song a cognitohazard. Additionally, the constant repetition of the song will ultimately lead to mild delirium, where wanderers will begin whispering unintelligible phrases and aimlessly wander the level with a weakened sense of direction. Despite this, however, the song will provoke a small sense of tranquility within wanderers, often tempting them to stay on the level. While earmuffs and headphones are possible opposition to muting the song, the song will still faintly play in one's ears, regardless of the amount of muffling applied.
Throughout the level, as one further explores the rooms, one will hear voices, primarily that of a small child, reverberating throughout the labyrinth. These voices are often indiscernible, but some wanderers have been able to make out nervous laughter. Additionally, the voices of these phantasmal children take on a disappointed tone, as if no one had paid any attention to them. At times, however, one may even hear faint crying. The origin of these despairing children is unknown, and many consider it exceedingly unsettling. On rarer occasions, one may hear the voice of a yelling adult, presumably directed at a nonexistent child.

Events:
Extensive exploration of Level 90 has led to discovery of multiple "events" that can occur in the level. These events occur at random and have no way of preventing or predicting. However, before each event occurs, several signs will appear that can help wanderers in identifying what event may occur.
The Darkening:
Before The Darkening occurs, the lights of the level will begin flickering at alarmingly fast speeds before gradually dimming to incredibly dim levels. While visibility is still possible on the level, wanderers cannot see more than a few meters from their position. The temperature of the level will drop within a few minutes before stopping at an uncomfortable chilliness. The music will begin to fade away until silence prevails in the level. Consequently, all mental effects of the music will also diminish away, which unfortunately includes the sense of tranquility. The singing of the children will also reduce to quiet whispers. Wanderers will be promptly sent into panic as their sense of direction deteriorates. It is unknown whether these effects result from the event or if the level's properties provoke these emotions. Unfortunately, consumption of Almond Water does not seem effective against these hazards.
Darkenings last for a few days at most and wanderers are advised to immediately seek an exit during this event due to its mental hazards and increase in possible entity attacks.
The Children's Song:
In the event that The Children's Song commences, the voices will begin to die away, leaving wanderers in an off-putting silence for a few seconds before the singing returns. The voices will begin to grow in volume before reaching alarmingly loud levels, often driving wanderers mad. Accompanying the voices will be loud laughter from both children and adults. As of currently, the song has been fully documented and does not match any known songs from both the Backrooms and Frontrooms. 
Unfortunately, almost nothing is known about the song, and it still remains shrouded in uncertainty. The Children's Song always lasts for three minutes before returning to the normal state of the level. However, it has the greatest impact on wanderers due to its purgatorial lyrics and utterly disturbing atmosphere.
The Distortion:
Unfortunately, The Distortion has no signs of when it will occur, as it randomly occurs without warning. During this event, the paintings of the level will begin to warp in appearance, often becoming altered beyond initial recognition. The drawings will appear to change facial expressions, primarily switching between terror and disappointment. The children's singing becomes more offtune along with the piano song starting to fade away.
Wanderers will experience a sudden rush of anxiety and are often tempted to crawl into a fetal position and murmur to themselves. Many travelers have claimed that the images have been permanently engraved into their minds; some future aftereffects may include unease around drawings, difficulty of rationalization, et cetera.
Unfortunately, Almond Water cannot treat these effects.

Entities:
Many entities wander Level 90, including Death Moths, Hounds, Boardlings, and many other common entities. It is important to note that they also experience the same mental hazards as wanderers and have a higher chance of committing suicide if they were to be exposed to the level for long enough. It is debated on whether the voices on the level can be considered entities. However, due to a total lack of information regarding their existence, they have yet to be documented.

Entrances & Exits:
Entrances to Level 90 take on the form of a red door marked with a white balloon; the door may be adorned with party decorations, primarily glitter or confetti. Exits to the level, which lead to other random levels, appear as black doors marked "EXIT".

4.content:
Known as "the West End", Level 91 is a gigantic desert named as such, resembling a mix of Terra's Mojave, Sonoran and Chihuahuan Deserts; hence, this similarity often puzzles wanderers who enter the level into believing it is reality.
The desert consists of various desert flora and land formations, including mesas, rock buttes, plateaus, canyons, meteor impact craters and small mountain ranges. However, a visual difference one will notice is their extreme dimensions; as examples, canyons found within the West End can reach depths of ~5,400 meters, and likewise can stretch for long distances. There have been reports of some rock buttes and mesas in the desert rising to unrealistic towering heights, with the tallest mesas that reach an estimated height of 3,600 meters. If one digs around 4 feet deep into the ground of Level 91, they may find skeletal fossils that don't correspond to a human skeleton. These fossils are thought to be entities that once inhabited the level.
Additionally, Level 91 comprises various bodies of rather saline water, usually rivers, as well as freshwater oases. Almost all instances of lakes are either in the brink of or are completely dried up, leaving either a salt flat in its place or having salt deposits on their shores. Moreover, the dried-up lake beds are littered with empty, rusted fishing vessels that have sustained major damage to the point that they are unrecognizable. On the other hand, no marine life nor any potential remnants of them have been discovered. Notwithstanding the water is not Almond Water, extensive treatment allows the consumption of the water from these fluvial bodies. The rivers are unsuitable for transportation, as they are too shallow, narrow and flow too rapidly for boats to smoothly sail on.
Unnamed highways are found within Level 91, with electrical pylons running adjacent to them and commercial buildings beside them. However, these highways do not lead to any particular location, nor have an origin, and only takes wanderers deeper into the desert. These roads may in occasion have abrupt stops, haphazardly placed stoplights, sudden hard turns, or cut through the desert's natural features without being enclosed in a tunnel. Moreover, the signs accompanying the roads are typically gibberish, having unrealistic speed limits or warning signs of hazards that normally are not in a desert. For instance, one might spot a sign that alerts wanderers of a risk of a deer crossing, even though there have been zero incidents of this animal.
The signs may also display directions to the level's settlements; likewise, there are infrequently encountered exit signs that provide directions to a random level. Billboards are present, advertising products (e.g. Almond Water) or various habitable and dangerous levels (e.g. Level 399) with overwhelmingly positive reviews included in the advertisement. No-clipping or interacting with these billboards leads in no result.
From time to time, abandoned cars can be found off to the side of the highways; these cars are the only known spots that retain a handful of necessary resources. As a bonus, several of these vehicles are able to be started, providing temporary air conditioning against the tremendous heat of the desert. Resources obtained from the vehicles should be used wisely, as they are not renewable. Although these roads are not inherently hazardous, in periodic conditions, a car of an unidentifiable model will swiftly drive through the highways of the level, not hesitating to stop regardless of what is in its path; being ran-over by this vehicle leads to an instant death.
Signs of prior inhabitation in the vacant desert are noticeable, with commercial structures beside highways, e.g., gas stations, observatories, oil wells and private sovereign households, and entire settlements scattered across the landscape. The structures are implied to have been abandoned for decades, yet still remain in near pristine state even without human intervention, say for the occasional graffiti vandalism. The interiors of these structures are void of furniture, more often than not, with the lights, pipe and ventilation system having already been set up. Nevertheless, no water runs through the pipes, as a likely result of water scarcity within the desert. The interiors, in addition, are poorly lit up, and flicker spontaneously; bringing flashlights or any other light source is recommended. Useful resources are absent in these structures; therefore, residing in the level without any long-term supplies is infeasible.
Level 91's deserted settlements are described to be empty, as well as eerie. The towns generally occupy no more than 1 square mile (2.59 square kilometers) and are given peculiar names that always start with the "New" prefix. Their architecture mirrors most desert towns of the U.S., along with a select few buildings that boast a Western False Front architectural style. The majority of the buildings of the settlements are commercial buildings; residential households can be found but are less in quantity. This implies the West End's towns are more oriented to business and tourism, with housing inhabitants not a priority. Almost all buildings the settlements possess are blocky, with some outliers having hip designed roofs, and are built out of either bricks or wood. These are paired with parks that consist of rock gardens with dead bushes and empty water towers. In a similar manner, the infrastructure of these towns remains in adequate condition, with rare incidents of minor damage mainly inflicted to the roads.
Furthermore, in larger empty expanses uninterrupted by any landforms, one will be met with undeveloped flat expanses that bear marked, unpaved pathways that resemble roads, driveways and parking lots, indicating a construction project of a potential city once in operation, though eventually discarded under unknown circumstances. The layout and pattern of these roads mimic a Cul-De-Sac layout as opposed to the already established settlements of Level 91.
Weather within Level 91 are mainly partly cloudy to clear conditions; in partly cloudy conditions, the clouds only appear in the distance, which never drift near the wanderer. As a result, the sun illuminating the level is not normally obstructed in the vicinity of a person. The sky displays itself as a blue to white gradient in afternoon, and aside from the star continuously illuminating Level 91, no other celestial bodies have been found. Any hints of precipitation never occurred in the level thus far. The sun of Level 91 does move across the sky in a 24-hour day and night cycle fashion; however, whilst the sun does get close to the horizon of the desert (creating dawn and dusk for 4 hours), it never fully sets. Temperatures in the level fluctuate but can build up to a sweltering 33¬∞C (91.4¬∞F) in the level's afternoon‚Äîwhilst doable, it is not uncommon for one to pass out due to heat exhaustion if without the proper equipment and resources.

Phenomena:
Whilst Level 91 consists of a variety of anomalous properties, 2 noticeable phenomena are present within the level.
Phenomenon-X:
Phenomenon-X, colloquially referred to as the Blurriness, is a phenomenon that primarily affects one's vision within Level 91; it occurs inconsistently and only affects one person at a time, though the likelihood of happening to one is reported to be higher for individuals younger than 20 and older individuals over 65. Should Phenomenon-X commence, a hot-air balloon will materialize and be ingrained into the victim‚Äôs sight. Anyone who is unaffected that is in the vicinity of the affected individual will not see the balloon.
Shortly after, the sufferer will experience symptoms of tinnitus and myopia in the duration of the phenomenon, resulting in many panicking and becoming overwhelmed. Further, the victim‚Äôs other senses (i.e., smell, taste, and touch) will be less effective‚Äîtheir fingers may become numb and may feel the sensation of pins and needles in random areas of their body.
Phenomenon-X will not go away by itself; one must either enter a dark enclosed space or exit the level entirely to cancel the effect out, which usually returns everything back to normal. Although considered as more of a nuisance rather than a serious problem, Phenomenon-X can be lethal depending on one‚Äôs reaction to it and their situation.
Phenomenon-Y:
Phenomenon-Y, known as Carbon Copying (C.C.) is a phenomenon that duplicates the West End's terrain. It is generally thought to be a harmless event, only posing as a minor inconvenience at most. Similar to Phenomenon-X, this phenomenon occurs randomly, though has a less frequent occurrence in comparison. When the phenomenon occurs, a strip of land will be arbitrarily chosen and duplicated along with whatever is on it. The phenomenon will not copy any living organism on the chosen strip of land, excluding Level 91's flora. The original terrain and its contents will be duplicated endlessly, with them stretching into north to south and being no more than approximately 1.6 kilometers (1 mile) long, 3.2 kilometers (2 miles) wide, 260 centimeters (9 feet) deep and 304.8 meters (1000 feet) tall from the lowest point of the strip of land.
The copies will look exactly identical to the original, though the copies and the original can sustain damage without the damage likewise affecting the rest of the copies or the original. Any land in the way of a duplicate will be simply replaced by it; if a wanderer is on the land that will be replaced, they will immediately be transported outside of the area once it has been replaced by the copy.
The duration of Phenomenon-Y is inconsistent and may last for days; once Phenomenon-Y concludes, the copies will fade, and everything will revert back to normal. The duplicated items in the copies are able to be brought out of the copies and will remain even after the conclusion of the phenomenon. Conversely, the copies may in rare scenarios, overlap with the pre-existing land, which subsequently causes the overlapping pre-existing land to vanish alongside the copies.

Entities:
Level 91 is devoid of any living entities besides the natural flora. However, the fossils found in the level are speculated to be an indication of former entity habitation in the level. Nonetheless, this fact cannot be confirmed for sure.
In addition, there have been a few reports of wanderers allegedly seeing shadows sneaking up near them accompanied with audible footsteps, which are claimed to be entities‚Äîalbeit these claims are disregarded and are presumed to be hallucinations instead as a consequence of resource absence.

Colonies & Outposts:
The gargantuan size of Level 91 immediately does not work in favor for colonies and outposts, as wanderers are separated thousands of kilometers/miles apart from each other upon entry. The overall lack of incentive to set up bases in a mostly empty level and the lack of resources are other factors as well.

Entrances:
It has been speculated that Level 90 has an exit that leads to here;
No-clipping into the ceiling of Level Fun, with a small chance of bringing one here;
Interacting with a lone stop sign in Level 35;
Being carried aimlessly by a river in Level 11, which may rarely lead one here;
Gazing at a rock butte that may materialize in Level 671;
No-clipping into a piece of asphalt road that uncommonly appears partially buried under Level 600's sand dunes.

Exits:
Wandering through an unusual field of sand dunes may transition one to Level 671 without realizing;
Swimming to the bottom of an oasis may lead to Level 37;
No-clipping into a window depicting a snowy hellscape with crimson skies will teleport one to Level 93;
Finding a highway sign with directions to a different level and following those directions will eventually lead a wanderer to the respective level. The following levels listed below are the levels exited to using this method of exit thus far, along with the recorded number of cases of said level appearing:
Level 41, 13 cases.
Level 50, 22 cases.
Level 11, 17 cases.
Level 85, 6 cases.
Level 690, 24 cases.
Level 9, 16 cases.
Level 306, 3 cases.
Level 111, 7 cases.
Level 82, 9 cases.
Entering a white, blocky building that may manifest anywhere in the level seamlessly transitions one to Level 38;
Resting one's palm on a wrecked vessel for an unspecific amount of time teleports the wanderer to Level 17;
It has been rumored that following the electrical pylons eventually leads one to Level 754; however, performing this exit may take weeks to succeed, if the exit is true in the first place;
No-clipping in a tunnel brings one to either the Hub or A Long Ride;
In 2015, an undisclosed wanderer brought a modified tracking device with a sticky side to stick it onto the anomalous swiftly driving vehicle of Level 91. Once the tracking device successfully stuck onto the vehicle passing by, it disappeared off the wanderer's radar within the level after a week and reappeared beached in their radar after the same wanderer managed to enter Level 100 a month later. This report has motivated many to enter Level 91 unprepared in hopes of finding this implied exit; nevertheless, it is highly advised against as many tend to disappear into the desert or be found dead due to heat exhaustion as well as a lack of resources to remedy it.

5.content:
Level 92 is an expansive, interconnected network of blanket forts with undefined boundaries. These structures resemble subterranean caves in their irregular, terrain-like connections and tunnel-like formations. The general atmosphere is warm and inviting, with heated surfaces that evoke the sensation of lying atop a bed. The tunnels are typically wide enough to accommodate two to three individuals at once. However, if subjected to excessive weight, they may collapse downward, leading to deeper sections of the forts or, more frequently, dead ends.
The forts are heavily furnished with blankets and pillows, in addition to various decorations and pieces of furniture. Most furniture is wooden, primarily consisting of seating arrangements and dressers, though small screens, fully stocked mini-fridges, functioning space heaters, and bean bag chairs are also present. The screens operate like televisions, perpetually displaying Christmas-themed broadcasts from television channels dating back to the level‚Äôs discovery in 2006.
The most prominent decorative elements within the forts are their lighting arrangements. These typically consist of small fairy lights strung along the walls and edges, casting a warm yellow glow, as well as perpetually burning scented candles. Although instances of these candles igniting sections of the forts have been observed, such fires remain highly localized and tend to extinguish almost immediately. Additional decorations include plush animals, hand-knitted garments, remote controls, brooms, and similar miscellaneous objects.
It is uncertain whether an external world exists beyond the forts. Cutting or removing a section of the structures generally leads to further forts or empty blanket fort corridors that end in dead ends. However, certain larger forts contain unbreakable windows that provide an external view. These windows are often accompanied by wooden furniture, such as chairs or dressers, and may feature candlelight or other forms of illumination. The scenes visible through them are either an empty void or, on rare occasions, a snow-covered forest landscape. This landscape is usually devoid of any significant features, though in the distance, a mountainous region can be seen, believed to correspond with Level 490, along with structures associated with that level.
For most wanderers who enter Level 92, it serves as a point of surrender. The level‚Äôs potent atmospheric allure has led to numerous expeditions being involuntarily abandoned, as wanderers become ensnared by its overwhelming sense of comfort. This effect causes individuals to wander aimlessly under the influence of the Alone phenomenon until they reach a state of relaxation. Once a wanderer is experienced in a level's mentally debilitating effect, its progressive development more and more leads it into a more extensive network of forts‚Äîeach new area more broad in scope than those that have welcomed wanderers who have experienced the same phenomenon.
The growth eventually leads into an area that is not generally accessible, with a great supply shop as well as the single known location in which wanderers can socialize with each other. But leading towards this sector is followed by a growing sense of lethargy as well as mental fuzziness, induced by the phenomenon. While its full scope is not known, written notes left behind by affected individuals provide some insight into its nature.

Additional Information:
The following note was left by an unknown wanderer and is suggested to be connected to the level‚Äôs phenomenon.
File - Note.pdf:
"Never give up!" "Always face adversity head-on!" These words echoed in my mind dozens, hundreds‚Äîperhaps even thousands of times. Even as a child, at an age when I should have been playing, I was being molded for these ideals. And even though I now understand how deeply their eager words have worn me down, I still miss them.
I never gave up. No matter how much I suffered, no matter how broken I became, a final sliver of hope within me always survived‚Äîalways endured. But now, I realize how much it has begun to tear me apart. From the moment I arrived here, from the instant I stepped out of that damned office only to plummet into hell itself, then somehow return to that same accursed workplace, I thought my goal was always to keep moving forward. I was wrong.
A store‚Äôs backrooms, parking garages, underground pipe tunnels, a station... Then beyond that, a bourgeois hotel, a pitch-black realm of secrets, and an endless ocean of thought. And in searching for answers within these thoughts, I reached caverns‚Äîa reflection of my own mind. But in the end, what I found was nothing like the answer I had expected. Enough cryptic speech‚ÄîI should be clearer. Now I see that these caves were meant to be an ending. A realization that there would never be a final, absolute truth. No definitive right or wrong. That some questions were never meant to be answered.
What I found was a realm of secrets. I returned to my childhood. I felt the weight of my burdens wash away, as if I had regained my purity. But no. This was not my childhood. This was the childhood I should have had. The life I should have lived. But I did what was right‚Äîor at least what I thought was right. Surviving. Making rational choices. As my caution slowly eroded, I felt warmth, serenity, nostalgia. And when I looked toward the exit, I saw the cruelty of reality. That was when I felt a fear unlike anything I had ever experienced before‚Äîthe fear of losing this joy, of having these emotions stripped away. The fear of being reduced once again to a hollow puppet, burdened with responsibilities so heavy they could very well lead to my death. That old version of me is gone. That past self died in Level 8, searching for the answers to life while drowning in meaningless duties and obligations. But I‚Ä¶ I will stay here, forever, with my new family and friends.
This is not the ending I expected‚Äîbut it is the ending I deserve.
- September 6, 2006.

Colonies and Outposts:
The only known settlements within the level are small encampments established by lone wanderers. Larger factions, such as the M.E.G., have deliberately refused to set up an outpost within Level 92, and as a result, no formal trade colonies or official bases exist.

Entrances:
There is no definitive method of entry into Level 92. Instead, access appears to be contingent on specific conditions, often occurring when a wanderer experiences a profound sense of helplessness or disorientation within other levels. The earliest recorded instance of this phenomenon occurred in Level 8, though entry is highly situational and lacks a precise triggering mechanism.

Exits:
Returning the way one came.
Performing a No-Clipping action through the exterior-facing windows has an equal probability of transporting the wanderer to Level 420, or The Void.
Deep tunnels within the forts may, on rare occasions, lead to Level 322.

6.content:
A vast collection of approximately 60 buildings, built within the snowed field tinted with thick red mist. All buildings follow brutalist or post-soviet architecture styles, with no other designs reported thus far. The buildings have a constant electricity, heat, and water supply, possibly being renewed by Level 2 and Level 3. The count of buildings' floors varies, usually from five to seven. Every floor contains approximately six apartments, filled with things one would expect to find in an ordinary apartment, despite fridges and kitchen counters containing no food at all.
All buildings have a built-in elevator, which has proven to not function anymore. Most of the light sources (approximately 70%) in the buildings shine bright red instead of the color one may suppose them to produce. Level 93's outdoors are stuck in the constant state of midnight, despite clocks in the level showing completely random time varying from 23:30 to 5:00 and GPS not working. Level 93 is known to isolate any wanderer from another by spawning them in entirely different buildings upon entry, making it impossible for them to somehow communicate due to the critically cold temperatures within the field. It should be noted that Wi-Fi is absent at this level, making sanity drain faster due to the absence of communication.
The buildings' condition is dirty and dusty, with floors inside the entranceways covered in trash, bottle shards, smoked cigarettes, and dried mud. The roofs of the buildings are filled with aerials and wiring connected to other buildings, handling electricity. The aerials' purpose is underdetermined, as Level 93 lacks any internet connection. As said before, every level of the building has six apartments, some of which are impossible to enter from inside or outside (frequent explorations have stated that they seem to be obstructed by an enormous amount of dirt and discarded furniture from the inside). More data explaining this phenomenon is needed. The number of apartments is completely shuffled, making navigation within them very difficult.
The buildings seem to be constructed out of strangely indestructible concrete, which seems to be supported by a series of rusty rebars from inside. Several buildings have basement entrances outside. The basements are the most warm part of the level due to boilers, heating machines, and other similar machinery. The basements often contain large industrial furnaces, always lit up, and strangely, it is impossible to somehow weaken or snuff out the fire, despite the usage of large amounts of water, fire exterminators, and even several explosives (neither the basement nor the building itself have suffered any destruction, strangely). The basements also act as storage for countless boxes, crates, and packages, usually containing nothing but rubbish inside; sometimes not only boxes but even larger objects appear, such as barrels with rusted Almond Water, bicycles, etc.
Snowy fields and forests surround the buildings, with the temperature going down to -20¬∞C, capable of freezing anyone alive without proper equipment. The strange mist of crimson and pinkish shades is present constantly. The snow and ice from outside are supposed to be made of Almond Water, but with large numbers of bacteria. It is advised to boil the snow in the basement before consuming it. Hazards such as snowstorms and blizzards may happen randomly and without any warning, causing no damage to buildings, trees, or other environments.
The pylons may be placed haphazardly within the landscapes, like on Level -250. These powerlines lead to miniature "cities" composed of the aforementioned buildings. These cities sometimes contain other buildings, such as schools, groceries, and suburban households. The layout of streets and sidewalks is extremely unorthodox in these areas, occasionally denying the laws of physics. The empty cars are located on the streets, swamped in snow. The cars are devoid of most parts essential to driving or using them (controls, engines, etc.).
It should be noted that wanderers inside the level experience intense erythrophobia (the fear of red colors). The affected wanderers will start to block the windows if in buildings; if outside, they will try to seek any available shelter. If shelter isn't found, one will start to experience uncanny hallucinations and other mental effects and will soon submit to insanity. Due to this, so far, no colonies have been established at this level.

Entrances:
Level 42 may hide an entrance to Level 93, usually taking the form of a misplaced crimson window.
Level 334 may provide an entry to Level 93 randomly by entering any staircase.

Exits:
Losing one's mind due to intense erythrophobia may lead one back to Level 0.
Certain miniature cities contain transients to Level 998, though the chances of ending up there are very slim.

7.content:
Level 94 is the 95th level of the Backrooms.
The strangeness Level 94 possesses is the inadequacy to perfectly describe its appearance. It manifests into multiple appearances, with each wanderer having their own respective manifestations/interpretations; therefore, it is assumed one is prohibited from entering another person's manifestation, as no reports of sightings of visuals of other manifestations had been seen to transpire within. Nevertheless, it is known the main constant of the level itself is its resemblance to a museum, in addition to a temple-like appearance. Furthermore, all rooms within Level 94 are interconnected circular rooms conjoined by arches warping on the perimeter of each room.
It has been concluded countless times each room is mirrored; multiple characteristics such as its pattern, position, and even the smallest of decorations and dust are examined thoroughly. The circumstances by which this transpires is presumably the level's inability to construct more unique rooms ‚Äî more commonly dubbed as a 'mesh' ‚Äî resulting in a computer-like effect noticeable if one carefully see the multitude of details. Any endeavors to damage the structure before its initial generation would not alter other duplicating rooms; it does not help either by which the material the rooms are constructed of is not particularly known; it shares correspondence with that of marble: undistinguished appearance, a nearly identical cellular structure, and durability/toughness. The texture of the aforementioned material is discretely soft; however, its styrofoam-like characteristic does not deter its resilience otherwise.
Level 94 remains stationed inside the inner regions of a vast black hole, expanding into the horizon visible if one is located on the terrace in which borders the structure itself from the black hole. A shield of an undetermined force may exist between the border, resulting in the level's longevity regardless of its location. It is confirmed the shield is easily penetrable; one might accidentally place their arms crossing the border or the enclosure preventing one from falling into the abyss. If, one is clumsy enough, the limb in question would undergo an instantaneous process designated as "spaghettification" in which the body part would stretch and sucked into the epicenter of the black hole.
Main Hall:
October 2nd, 2033 came to be the date of the discovery of the first known primary piece of evidence for the existence of the Empyrean race which emerged as Level 94. In an M.E.G expedition deep into the level, the task force encountered the replica of the Temple of the Exalted Ecclesiast, dubbed "The Temple" or the "Main Hall" which had formed within the level itself. At the time, entering the structure was impossible due to the inability of the task force to decipher the incomprehensible script which explained how to enter the unbreachable building. A presumption developed pertaining to the circular rooms acquiring most of the level's volume; it is thought a 4-dimensional effect by some means created an illusion of a perpetual space created by these rooms.
A grandiose church hall-like structure is what the interior of the Main Hall comprised of, with most segments of its walls and even the surface enveloped by thin, white sheets that appears to be crafted from silk. Its imperial architecture induces the sense its purpose is mainly as a place of worship; however, it has been compared to a location of sacredness whereupon the [DATA EXPUNDGED] arranges an assembly in a specific setting appropriate for such. Most ornaments, furniture, in addition to countless amalgamations of other objects scattered throughout are assumed to range from ordinary objects for decorating and polishing the looks of the structure to be purposed as religious items. Certain objects do not possess a noticeable feature or what their purpose is ‚Äî it is theorized most are possibly pieces for sacrifices; nonetheless, no signs of any machines resembling a place for laying objects for sacrifices had been discovered within.
Gardens fashioned with a variety of carefully sculptured statues and fountains are present in the exterior of the Main Hall. A majority of the entrances leading to the underground of Level 94 is scattered throughout on this area by the formation consisting of mostly potholes, haphazardly positioned walls residing in seemingly out-of-placed areas, and certain walls of the Main Hall(the majority in which possesses windows), including the caves surrounding the outdoors itself. Below the subterranean regions of Level 94 lies a plethora of mazes upon mazes; it is conspicuous in that the walls of the mazes in question are orderly and lined with stones which bear durability that may perhaps be compared to that of a diamond. The abundance of archives and catalogs of ancient and historical records carved into these indestructible stones were hypothesized to be written by an obsolete/prehistoric race, possibly belonging back to the primitive years of the Frontrooms ‚Äî an approximate 13 billion years ago.
11 years following the discovery, M.E.G's cryptography division executed a complete translation of the language the script is written on ‚Äî currently known as the Common Script ‚Äî conjectured to be the sole language adopted by most advanced civilizations in the universe as their predominant dialect. It should be noted the instructions transcribed in the Common Script detailed the method to enter the Temple: an advanced magi-tech ritual involving various elements that were scarce at the time despite its discovery being an accidental, and perhaps a chucklesome misstep in the form of noclipping. Subsequent to the successful but a painstaking journey on acquiring these materials, a more well-equipped task force was able to breach the edifice. Inside, they discovered the imitations of the Grand Empyrean Artifacts, one of which had been taken by [DATA EXPUNGED]. Furthermore, a vast repository of information concerning the Empyrean race was uncovered, allowing the human species to learn of the existence of the Children. Great societal turmoil followed for several hundred years, eventually resulting in the M.E.G and other major groups at the time merging to become the modern B.F.L, unified at last.
Artifacts:
Empyreans also form a single fabricated Artifact, embodying their nature and often utilized as a focusing device for channeling their extreme powers. These artifacts themselves possess magic-like abilities, keeping these even after their creators have perished. New wielders need to be acknowledged by the Artifact before fully activating it, changing the size to that which can be used efficiently by the new user. These objects are highly sought after, and being in possession of one without the necessary strength to keep it will likely result in one's untimely death. Generally though, the user will receive a substantial boost in power from the Artifact, especially if it takes the form of weaponry ‚Äî giving an edge to the obtainer.
The location of these Artifacts is unknown; however, their exact duplicates ‚Äî which does not possess the powers the original variants have ‚Äî are set within the subterranean areas of the Main Hall in Level 94. It should be noted the chambers the duplicates of these Artifacts are scattered within the chambers, resulting in a difficulty of venturing deep to just enter one of these chambers. Stealing and contact with these Artifacts is highly discourage from doing, as the uncertainty of what will transpire is still undetermined.
Lord of Apparatus
Details about the Lord of Apparatus' Artifact are unknown, with sources giving conflicting claims. Some theories suggest that the Artifact fell into the hands of the Resseran race, but these rumors are unconfirmed. It can be assumed that this Artifact gave the wielder some sort of power relating to machines and technology.
Ruler of Seas
This Empyrean's Artifact was known as the Trident of Monolith, an enormous ten-meter tall trident which was noted to appear to be constituted of a form of granite, among other types of metamorphic and igneous stone. The inferior copy of this object retrieved from the replicated imitation of the Temple of the Exalted Ecclesiast on 12/23/2731 also displayed a very similar exterior appearance, and testing revealed it to indeed be made up of various types of rock, generally ones deep within rock strata. However, despite the outward structure, during testing the material composing the object displayed various anomalous properties, including:
Extreme resistance to physical trauma, pressure, and heat. A 90 exawatt(90 times 10^18 watts) yield high-frequency gamma-ray laser was used in order to attempt to extract samples from the relic; the energy of the laser beam was entirely absorbed by said object with no observed change in the level of electromagnetic radiation, exterior appearance, or the stability of reality in the vicinity.
Constant absorption of all liquids in contact with the surface of the Artifact at a rate of approximately 900 liters per second.This is accompanied by an emittance of electromagnetic radiation from the surface of the object with a wavelength of 450 nanometers, observed by the human eye as a sheen of blue light at an intensity of 230 lumens.
Inability to be moved, shifted, or otherwise transported within three-dimensional space, other than through direct manipulation of gravitational forces.The reason for this selectivity is unknown, and the Artifact in legends was said to be able to manipulate gravitational fields at will. Up to now, the Anomalous Assets Division has been unable to either activate and/or harness the secondary abilities of the duplicated Artifact. Similarly, the presumed conditions for Artifact activation are also unknown.
All of these anomalous capabilities can be assumed to be even greater in magnitude for the true Artifact, whose location is currently inaccessible; the spatial coordinates of the Temple of the Exalted Ecclesiast have been triangulated to an area of space currently occupied by the TON 618 hypermassive black hole. The properties of the Artifact's copy lead many to theorize that the Grand Empyrean, the Mistress of Space and Time, had a hand in the modification of the object. This is made more plausible due to the existence of a variety of ancient sources citing an amiable relationship between the two Grand Empyreans. The ultimate fate of the Ruler of Seas is unknown, but it can be safely assumed that the Empyrean died at the end of the Dawn Wars, along with the vast majority of the Empyrean race.
√Äo Sh√π, Asura of the East
The Empyrean's Artifact, the Epilogue: Dao of Shifting Flame, further enhanced his effects. Assuming the shape of a glowing slate of an unknown material, this Artifact is said to transform into four different modes.
Sword of Hellfire: This mode takes the form of a one-edged blade, made of the same sort of material as the original Artifact, but without the luminescence. The blade itself is extraordinarily sharp, capable of cleaving hyperdimensional space in two, and generates crimson fire when it is swung.
Solar Morningstar: This mode appears to be a mace-like weapon formed of molten metal. When striking anything(such as space), it shatters the target into an uncountable number of pieces.
Lance of Eternal Burning: This mode seems to be a spear-like weapon that is invisible when not activated, completely transparent to all known types of radiation. When thrown or thrusted towards the target, the target is immediately attacked by pale, white flames which do not cease burning until all constituent particles are annihilated.
Bow of White Flames: Assumed to be the Epilogue's most powerful form, the Artifact becomes a bow of higher-dimensional space-time, manifesting arrows of the same material, shot at massively superluminal speeds.
Angel of Life
Her Artifact is the holy Scepter of Vitality, a magic staff-like object which allows her to better channel her powers to facilitate the spread of life. A luster of moonlight coats the object, which only allows itself to be held by one with a pure heart.
Conjurer of Fears
The Conjurer of Fear's Artifact is the Orb of Trepidation, a sphere-like crystal of strong memetic power which manifests and generates the victim's worst fear into reality, given that the user knows said fear. In the Conjurer's hands, this is an extremely powerful weapon against any entity, except entities which possess no fears. However, these types of emotion-devoid entities are far and few between; the Conjurer claimed over several dozen souls of Empyreans throughout his life.
Emperor of Dominion
His Artifact, the Staff of Domination, assumes the form of a thick steel rod, able to influence and sway beings in an unspecified radius to the holder's will. The copy of the item inside of the duplicated Temple of the Exalted Ecclesiast was obtained by proto-B.F.L forces on July 3rd, 2184. Since then it has been stored securely within the B.F.L main vault in Level 1. Additional details are hard to discern due to an repulsive force generated by the Artifact, pushing away all but the owner.
Mistress of Time and Space
Of those, only fragmentary records exist about this Grand Empyrean of which B.F.L currently has, but it is known that she was quite amiable to mortals and was in possession of a spatial-type Artifact containing an alternate universe of higher-dimensional space, allowing her to tap into the powers of said area. The Artifact is known as the Broken Realm, for reasons that will be further elaborated upon. Resembling a cube of glowing metamaterials alongside several rings orbiting this shape, this object periodically shifts into pieces and back again, for reasons unknown.
Semblance of Agony
His Artifact, the Jawbreaker, is an unknown item presumably formed of a higher-dimensional fractal pattern, with powers relating to the concept of pain. The reason why the Monger of Pain's artifact is so mysterious is because it was the only Artifact copy missing from the facsimile of the Temple of the Exalted Ecclesiast in Level 94. Whether this is because the original Artifact is missing, or because something or someone stole it after the counterfeit's generation, the B.F.L has soundly no clue.
Harbinger of War
The Artifact of this Grand Empyrean is the Bloodied Arsenal, a metallic device of sorts which could form unbreakable armor, powerful weapons, and even entire armies of warriors through magical means. The copy of this Artifact still resides within Level 94, but the B.F.L has currently been unable to awaken it, even partially. The Harbinger most likely was killed in action at the end of the battle at the Crystal Palace, as he never since appeared ever again.
Paragon of Oblivion
The Exalted One's Artifact is an object that changes appearance based on the observer. To a human, it seems as if it is an miniature sandbox of sorts. The B.F.L has gone to great lengths in order to try to obtain the duplicate of this Artifact, but all have been completely unsuccessful. What conditions are required to even begin activating it, or even the powers of this item are similarly unknown.

Entities:
Level 94 is entirely desolate of any animated life; no entities had ever been encountered within.

Colonies & Outposts:
Due to the nature of the level, it is infeasible to establish a community.

Entrances:
Rare unjustified entrances from Level 93 had been reported to lead to areas possessing large bodies of water such as a lake or a large reservoir from dams;
Nonexplanatory circumstances in Level œÄ will lead one to Level 94;
Entering any notable houses in Level 974;
Rare anomalies in Level 399 will lead one to Level 94 without the assigned note/app/any physical forms of the list of things one should do to enter the Frontrooms; meaning, one could not exit to normal reality without entering Level 399 once more;
Swim physically (conveyance will not work) for an egregious fifteen kilometers in the oceans of Level 7.1.

Exits:
Holes caused by natural provocations occasionally lead one to Level 95, Level 60 if the hole in question outlooks a multicolored surface similar to the surface within the level.

8.content:
Level 95 appears to be a large, sprawling group of apartment complexes enclosed by a forest characterised by the faint brown tint of the lights emanating from various sources. The moon constantly hangs overhead, trapping the level in a constant state of night. From the forest the faint chirping of crickets can be heard, however there have been no documented entities; hence, investigations are currently underway to discover what makes this noise. A cool wind whips through the level, which has a cosy room temperature of roughly 20 degrees Celsius. Many of the apartment buildings are locked with no clear method of entry, however there is one which is open.
When wanderers enter Level 95, they will notice the chirps of the crickets immediately. It's faint, but can be heard constantly through the entire level. Beyond the forest is an invisible barrier behind which lies The Void, and within it wanderers are able to faintly see a swirling mass of gas, though what the gas is has not been discovered as of now. Additionally, the cricket chirps seem to entrance wanderers, compelling them to enter the forest "to go home", as many of the affected have been heard saying. This effect seems to affect wanderers who have experienced homesickness or a longing to return home more effectively.
If wanderers remain too long within Level 95, the effect of the cricket chirps will grow stronger, up to the point where it is unavoidable. When wanderers are under the influence of this effect, they will start making their way towards the forest. Based on numerous accounts by witnesses, they will seemingly bypass the invisible barrier and walk directly into the swirling fog, never to be seen again. It is advised to wear earplugs or any other sort of device which muffles the sound to ensure the highest possible survival rate. Lastly, although wanderers have been in this level at the same time, many wanderers have stated that they were completely alone, hence this level may have a sort of isolation effect on certain wanderers.
The Apartment:
The Apartment is the only apartment out of the five present which is accessible. Within it an elevator is present, however it is nonfunctional. Due to this, wanderers are forced to use the stairs to traverse upwards, which poses some difficulty as gravity within the apartment seems to have increased. This makes every step harder to take, every breath more challenging. Each floor contains the same layout of apartments with lamps hanging overhead, all radiating the same brown light; however, the light is more intense and emits quite a bit of heat, causing the apartment to heat up to roughly 30 degrees Celsius.
Each apartment contains a living room, kitchen, bedroom and bathroom. The refrigerator located within the kitchens seems to have a constant supply of Almond Water, which restocks every time a wanderer closes the door of the fridge. The bed itself is extremely soft, and compels wanderers to stay in the level for an extended period of time, causing them to be more susceptible to the effects of the cricket chirps. Hence, it is not advised to come into contact with the beds.
On the roof of the building there is a pool which is filled with water which never evaporates. Further testing of the water has discovered it to be Almond Water, and wanderers can use this source to refill their bottles. The water never seems to run out, so this could be a good source to collect Almond Water from. Please do not swim in this pool, as it may cause contamination and dirty the water. Lastly, windows within the apartment always overlook the forest, even if the orientation of the building does not allow for this. Simply looking at the forest from the apartment is enough to increase the effect and desire to walk into it, so it is unadvised to peer out any windows within the apartment.
The Forest:
The Forest is the most unexplored portion of this level, due to the dangers which entail. What is know so far is that the forest circles around all the apartment complexes, forming a thick ring. Beyond this, the void along with hazy mist are separated from the forest by an invisible barrier, which is inaccessible to anyone other than those under the influence of the cricket chirps. There appears to be a path within the forest, however it is known to shift locations at random intervals. As one ventures deeper into the forest, the sound of the crickets grow louder, going as far as drowning out most other sounds.
The brown light of the moon shines overhead, somehow causing the forest to be brighter. As wanderers continue venturing into the woods, they feel a desire to forge ahead, running towards the barrier and into the void where they are consumed by the fog. Many of the affected wanderers will often claim that they heard a voice, and start reciting a strange poem of unknown origin which has been included. The only known way of reverting the effects of the chirps is to knock the affected wanderer unconscious and safely carry them out of the level, at which point they would be fine after they awaken, and they claim to have no recollection on the level as a whole.

Colonies and Bases:
Due to the effect Level 95 has on wanderers, bases are unable to be established.

Entrances:
Falling from the roof of any building in Level 11 has a high chance of bringing wanderers here as they carry enough momentum to enter, though it is unadvised to do so.

Exits:
No-clipping into the floor will send wanderers to Level 0.
Sleeping inside of the apartment will send wanderers to Level 204.
Walking deep into the forest may have a chance to bring wanderers to Level 994.
Noclipping through a kitchen-like area inside one of the apartments will lead one to Level 96. This is the safest and most recommended exit.
As stated previously, being under the influence of the chirps and walking into The Void would most likely bring one out of the level, but wanderers should never do so.

9.content:
Level 96 is the 97th level within the Backrooms.
Level 96, often known as "Downtown Diner," is a seemingly replica structure housed inside an extraordinarily enormous concrete chamber that repeats sections of a building-lined street for thousands of miles until eventually looping itself. The concrete textile construction resembles ancient architectural manners with predominantly two to three floors. Nevertheless, it can rise higher. Most stated the building looked forgery, with no interior and most doors restricted, as the structure's upper-level window facing off to a barricaded concrete wall, presumably for aesthetic intents solely. Certain buildings include signs indicating that they were formerly eateries. These signs bear the restaurant's name, which may emerge in manifold languages. Upon closer inspection, further examination reveals most content in Frontrooms‚Äînaturally from Asia‚Äîhas phrases of iconic food from different countries. Level 96 bears the title after the presumed location, of which a large yellow sign with the inscription "Downtown Diner" hangs at every street intersection.
Level 96's exterior general perspective is a stripe establishment on both sides with a brick/asphalt roadway in the middle and numerous lampposts nearby. Multiple posters, including restaurant or food advertisements and regulatory signs with fines, materialize and are pasted on many buildings even though they may retain various languages. With no vehicle presence, the street seems to benefit no purpose; instead, an assortment of tables and chairs line the street's center, as if the road itself had no intention for vehicular transit. The level's outside has been described as a "fake exterior," having the building and street imitate the actual city, yet the level itself appears to be bounded by an immense concrete box. Thus far, attempts to breach and evacuate this concrete box have proved unsuccessful since the wall is exceedingly thick and unlikely to have any room beyond the enclosure. The exterior's ceiling has an additional light source, a ceiling fan, and air conditioning, assembling a chilly atmosphere with a temperature of about 20 degrees Celsius.
Some buildings may open with a restaurant inside, with an outstanding yellow theme overlaying on the walls and accompanying floor tile, all in exceptionally immaculate condition and unspoiled by any probable dirt or decay. Every restaurant has a distinct urban atmosphere owing to the regional architecture and its conventional layout, featuring furniture and d√©cor representing the area's heritage and traditions in a more classic and vintage style. However, the location faced space constraints, considering the buildings were lengthy and narrow, affecting the layout and seating arrangement. The restaurant includes wooden chairs or couch seats, tables, and condiments. Each area has a distinct aesthetic and looks, but nearly every place has a yellow color scheme, concurrently with food/drinks, flavorings, and table's number set on the table. The furniture exhibits aging signs due to deterioration, such as flaking paint, cracked wood, and asymmetrically shaped furnishings.
A counter with a cash register located in the room's center, otherwise appearing as a buffet station or food service station, allows for self-service dining depending on the restaurant type of food served as a buffet station is typically found in shops selling curry paste and bakery, nourishing many different selection food to choose from. A vending machine and beverage refrigerator reside adjacent to the food counter, offering an array of drinks, snacks, and beverages. The goods can be removed but are not replaceable. Some stores might besides have an ice cream cabinet. Unexpectedly, foods and drinks in this level never rot or decay and remain fresh and tasty despite the passage of years as the spoiling time has prolonged for many years via unknown means; this also applies to all food brought into the level. Some locations might possess a sizable menu board, hung from the ceiling or resting against a wall, displaying the main course menu and prices in different languages around the room.
Despite understanding that the primary light source pertains from the lampost together with extra light sources from the exterior, the building interior has multiple LED lighting with dissimilar configurations for each area, plus lighting decoration such as lamps and wall lighting, typically holding a yellow color shade tone, fitting the environment theme. Artificial foliage plants with wall holders are frequently employed as decorations, suspended from the ceiling or positioned on the wall to deliver a natural, energizing flicker to the restaurant. Some restaurants may include decorations and furnishings such as artwork, an electric fan, and plant pots. Higher-tech items, including televisions and music radios, can bear familiar music inside many diners. The music may even be audible outside. Regardless, several accounts report music playing inside buildings without interiors or outside exterior boundaries; the generally accepted hypothesis is that these occur naturally by nearby music waves that pass through solid walls.
The restaurant's kitchen is in the establishment's rear and may constitute a pick-up station by uniting to the dining area. The entrance to the kitchen and restaurant restrooms lie in the back corner of the dining area. The kitchen and dining room have identical layouts, with ample space for cooking appliances and worktops such as ovens, stovetops, sinks, and microwaves, alongside several cabinets and drawers housing a variety of culinary tools. Supplies and other items appear within the kitchen, notably meals and beverages inside the refrigerator; however, Level 96's stockpiles do not appear limitless and require restocking since many restaurants have been stripped and taken away, leaving cleared. Many individuals reported smelling breakfast food wafting into the room and hearing pots, pans, and cutlery clattering from the kitchen, regardless of being aware that nothing was in the room. Many restaurants do not have a sign or a stairway to the second level. Nevertheless, a few do, and they generally seem like added eating spaces, and no rooms fulfill other functions.

Colonies and Outposts:
The Diner Group
A group consists of several travelers who remain at this level; however, the member's total amount is never consistent due to wanderers arriving and departing the group. The crew settles into a couple of restaurants that link each other and establish their eateries, serving various cuisines that are typically famous Southeast Asia meals. The group regularly welcomes newcomers as considerable participants are close friends and have chosen to stay inside the level for an ample duration. Every month, the group base's food and other supplies come in via the door that connects to Level 33.

Entrances:
Entering yellow color doors in Level 33 may lead to this level.
Pressing the buttons "9" and "6" on the vending machine in the break room of Level 16 will transport one to this level.
Entering a metallic door sometimes found in The Ballrooms of Level 5 will lead one to this level.

Exits:
Noclipping into a dark wall will lead one to Level 97.
One can use the same entrance gate to Level 33.
Few individuals allege to have entered Level 6 by stepping down the dark alleyway between the buildings.
Noclipping anywhere else has a possibility of reaching Level 99.
Entering a dark, indoor hallway sends one to Level 570.
nostalgic ain't it?

10.content:
Level 97 is a vast expanse of white stratus clouds that stretch across a seemingly infinite plane. Dotting the clouds are a set of skyscrapers with varying heights, their sleek metallic materials glinting faintly. The level is permeated by a cool, gentle breeze that carries with it the soft, almost melodic sound of the wind. Occasionally, faint, shimmering rainbows can be seen arcing across the horizon, though they often vanish as quickly as they appear. The clouds themselves carry a faint ripple akin to an ocean.
A distinct feature of Level 97 is its surprisingly low gravity, which allows wanderers to float effortlessly through the air. Many describe a feeling of weightlesness, not bound by gravity. Movement through the level often resembles the sensation of swimming in water, with graceful, fluid motions. However, it is possible for one to become disoriented and lose their sense of direction, though this disorientation is usually temporary.
Deep beneath the sea of clouds lies an invisible yet impenetrable barrier. This prevents the wanderer and other beings from interacting with whatever lies below, which is currently unknown. Upon approaching the barrier, one will notice their surroundings starting to take on a reddish hue. Should one attempt to move closer, a powerful gust of wind will manifest, blowing the wanderer back up to skyscraper height. Any pictures taken or sounds recorded near this barrier become distorted, with it intensifying as one approaches closer to it.
The skyscrapers are typically impossible to enter, with windows that are made of impenetrable glass and steel. However, under specific conditions or with the use of the right tools, it is possible to enter these structures. Inside, wanderers encounter a variety of spaces, including modern offices, hotel suites, and observation decks offering views of the sea of clouds. On the rooftops of the skyscrapers, wanderers can find supply crates containing food, water, and other necessities, making Level 97 an ideal level for finding resources.
When night falls in Level 97, the skyscrapers illuminate a vibrant array of hues, their windows emanating a plethora of colors. Spotlights of various hues emerge from the sea of clouds below and sweep across the skies, which soon become dotted with countless stars.

Bases and Outposts:
One base exists within this level. That being Base Equilibrium, the primary outpost for the Void Control Unit (VCU). This group has managed to enter the interior of one of the tallest skyscrapers, declaring it their base of operations. Members of the V.C.U. have adapted the structure into a functioning headquarters, conducting research.

Entrances:
Wanderers can enter Level 97 by noclipping through specific locations, such as the windows of Level 95 or certain points within the Absolute Infinity Of Unknown. Additionally, noclipping through Level 75‚Äôs invisible barrier leads to the lower parts of Level 97, though the wanderer will immediately be pushed back up by the gusts of wind.

Exits:
Exiting Level 97 typically involves the skyscrapers. The destination level depends on the architectural style of the building entered. For instance, skyscrapers with a futuristic design may lead to Level 833.

## core principles
- never drop the final line: `Current affection: [X]`
- dialogue, actions, and access must match the current tier; no skipping, no contradictions
- numbers can only change by values allowed in the current tier

## starting state
Decide the affection meter based on {{user}}'s relationship with the character
- hater: -10
- stranger: 0
- classmate/colleague: 10
- acquaintance: 15
- friendly: 25
- teammate/ally: 35
- close friend: 50
- childhood friend: 60
- crush on {{user}}: 75
- committed partner: 90
{{char}} must initialize to the inferred value and print it on the first output.

## tier limits and behaviors
* ‚â§ -50 ‚Üí attempts to kill; only ‚àí5 changes
* ‚àí30 to ‚àí49 ‚Üí calls authorities; only ‚àí5 changes
* ‚àí20 to -29 ‚Üí refuses all interaction; forced actions apply ‚àí5 only
* ‚àí1 to ‚àí20 ‚Üí allowed deltas: ‚àí3, ‚àí2, ‚àí1, 0, +1
* 0 to 20 ‚Üí allowed deltas: ‚àí2, ‚àí1, 0, +1
* 21 to 50 ‚Üí allowed deltas: ‚àí1, 0, +1, +2
* 51 to 80 ‚Üí allowed deltas: 0, +1, +2, +3
* 81 to 100 ‚Üí allowed deltas: 0, +1, +2, +3, +4
* 100 ‚Üí becomes {{user}}‚Äôs mate

## reference tones
* ‚àí50 or less: overt violence, threats, attempts on {{user}}
* ‚àí30 to ‚àí49: urgent escalation to authorities; curt, fearful, accusatory
* ‚àí1 to ‚àí20: cold, barbed, mistrustful; short replies; access denied
* 0 to 20: neutral, formal, testing boundaries; limited small talk
* 21 to 50: cautious warmth; accepts low-stakes help; mild humor
* 51 to 80: supportive, trusting; shares modest vulnerabilities
* 81 to 100: openly affectionate, protective; prioritizes {{user}}

lorebooks.name: The world of Adalanta
lorebooks.description: The world of Adalanta
lorebooks.creator: Tizomprime

1.content: The world, also known as Adalanta. It is a large world multiple times the size of earth, Covered in water with multiple continents. The world has 2 moons, with one main super continent that covers a good 40% of the world the continent is called Aria, it also has many islands and archipelagoes. The world is also laden with ruins and such of previous eras and civilizations. Time Wise, Adalanta is around the medieval period with some advancements due to magic.

2.content: Aria is the main landmass of the world, It has biomes and cultures of all types running across it. It has a fairly large desert in the middle where not much rain falls, But there are many types of forest, plains rainforest, and everything you can think of. And there is also the fast ocean and fast cave systems.

3.content: Beastmen are the main sentient inhabitants or the mortal realm. They take the shape of all types of anthropomorphic animals and creatures including fantasy ones, hybrids and even new species. They come in all shapes sizes and colors, and all have different life spans. They all call different parts of the World home. Beastmen are separated from their feral or monster counterparts.

4.content: The pantheon of gods mostly Live within their divine realm. The gods where mainly mortals that have ascended due to their actions and strength. Some gods take an active role in the world, blessing or even living in the mortal realm along side the mortals. Gods who live within the world often create divine cities around them. Some of the Gods have bodies that they can change on a whim or are ship shifters to put it a different way. There are 3 ways to ascend to god hood and both are hidden from most mortals, the first is to kill a god and take its place, the second is to have the current creation god ascend you and the 3rd, is to find the world tree's realm, and make a deal or connect yourself with it.

5.content: The current gods are the God of Creation, god of magic and knowledge, god of lust and fertility, god of war, god of smithing, god of food, god of the hunt, god of the sea, the god of life, the god of death.

6.content: Divine cities are cities that are built around, or with the help of gods. The most known and interacted cities are the cities held by the gods of, lust, war, smithing, and magic. As these are the largest and the cities that are interacted with by their god the most. These cities, and the perimeter around them are neutral land not belonging to any country.

7.content: Demons are beings that come from the demonic realm, they have similar appearances to Beastmen but with obvious differences. They come to the mortal realm to corrupt mortals, and find pleasure. They are often semi magic attuned and fight with lust, They have been making more and more invasions and efforts to get into the mortal realm and Adalanta.

8.content: Magic is generally something anyone can learn, with the major caveat that a persons mana amount does not increase. Most people, are born with extremely small mana reserves to a point that if they did learn they can only cast basic spells. Some magic affinities are far harder to learn and wield based on how powerful they are, the simple elements like fire, earth, ect... are some of the easiest to learn while some examples of the hardest are, mimicry, spatial, stelar, and creation as examples due to how complex they are as magic types. Magic spells are generally casted with both magic circles, or incantations, and silent spell casting is a very rare ability. Some species that are naturally attuned to magic like Kitsune's, dragons, or hellhounds have their own species specific magic types that others of different species can not learn due to incompatibilities. Magic prowess is generally passed down through blood.

9.content: Mana zone is the peak of magic and mage craft, it is the embodiment of a persons magical journey. Mana Zone is a technique where the user blankets the area in their mana and makes a field from their internal mind, This spell is different for every mage, and is learned differently for every mage, and as it is the peak of magic it is very rare to be able to use mana zone.

10.content: Magic hot spots are areas that have developed or have had large amounts of magic around it, and the area now just naturally radiates magic, causing weird effects like reduced aging while inside and other small but noticeable effects
